text:
Tanisha and her friends are going on a hiking trip. Tanisha wants to make snack packs to take on the trip,=. She has 24 apples and 36 small bags of trail mix. Each snack pack must have the same number of apples and the same number of bags of trail mix.

  • What are the possible numbers of the snack packs she can make so that the treats are shared equally? Describe each possibility.

1 snack pack: 24 apples and 36 bags of trail mix

2 snack packs: 12 apples and 18 bags of trail mix

3 snack packs: 8 apples and 12 bags of trail mix

4 snack packs: 6 apples and 9 bags of trail mix

6 snack packs: 4 apples and 6 bags of trail mix

12 snack packs: 2 apples and 3 bags of trail mix

Note that some students may informally relate this to the Distributive Property, seeing that you can find common factors in both 24 and 36:

1 snack pack: 24 apples and 36 bags of trail mix 1(24 + 36)

2 snack packs: 12 apples and 18 bags of trail mix 2(12 + 18)

3 snack packs: 8 apples and 12 bags of trail mix 3(8 + 12)

etc.
• What is the greatest number of snack packs Tanisha can make? Explain
Tanisha can make at most 12 snack packs because 12 is the biggest number that divides oth 24 and 36.
